title: My DIY drip-line IRRIGATION setup EXPLAINED while welding a BROADFORK!

tasks.task: Replace a tine on a broad fork and set up a drip line irrigation system.
subtasks: Fabricate a replacement tine for a broad fork.
Remove a thin tine from the broad fork.
Measure the width of the existing tines to ensure the replacement tine is the correct size.
Heat the replacement tine to make it more malleable.
Hammer the replacement tine into place on the broad fork.
Align the replacement tine with the existing tines on the broad fork.
Check the tightness of the replacement tine and make adjustments as needed.
Set up a drip line irrigation system.
Lay out the 40 mil pipe for the main irrigation line.
Install a filter at the start of the irrigation system.
Connect the filter to the 40 mil pipe.
Run the 32 reducing T from the filter to the 32 mil pipe.
Install ball valves along the 32 mil pipe for controlling individual beds.
Drill eight mil holes in the ball valves for the drip lines.
Insert pipa keys into the drilled holes to secure the drip lines.
Cut the drip lines to the appropriate length for each bed.
Install inline emitters and filters into the drip lines.
Connect the drip lines to the main 32 mil pipe.
bury the drip lines along the garden beds.
Wear clothing that matches the metal being welded.
Choose a blue jacket to blend with the UV arc light.
Avoid wearing white or bright colors that may reflect light and make the welder visible.

tasks.task: Prepare the garden for the drip line irrigation system.
subtasks: Remove and store the previous watering cans and equipment.
Prepare the garden beds for the new irrigation system.
Remove any existing plants that may interfere with the irrigation system.
Mark the positions where the drip lines will be installed.
Dig trenches for the drip lines to follow the garden beds.
Smooth and level the trenches for optimal pipe installation.

tasks.task: Irrigate the garden using the new system.
subtasks: Turn on the irrigation system and check for proper water flow.
Open the ball valves to supply water to the individual beds.
Monitor the system for leaks or clogs and make adjustments as needed.
Allow the system to run for the specified duration.
Shut off the irrigation system and return to the lab for further modifications.
